{{more citations needed|date=June 2011}} {{Infobox islands | name =Jamaica | image_name = Jamaica terrain.png | image_caption = Map of Jamaica | image_size = | map_image = Jamaica Topography.png | map_caption = | native_name = Xaymaca | native_name_link = | nickname = ''Land of Wood and Water'' | location = [[Caribbean Sea]] | coordinates = {{coord|18|15|N|77|30|W|display=inline,title}} | archipelago = [[Greater Antilles]] | total_islands = | major_islands = | area_km2 = 10911 | rank = 71st | length_km = 248 | width_km = 84 | coastline_km = 1022 | highest_mount = [[Blue Mountain Peak]] | elevation_m = 2256 | country = Jamaica | country_admin_divisions_title = | country_admin_divisions = | country_admin_divisions_title_1 = | country_admin_divisions_1 = | country_admin_divisions_title_2 = | country_admin_divisions_2 = | country_largest_city = [[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]] | country_largest_city_population = 651,880 | population = 2,804,332 | population_as_of = 2008 | density_km2 = 252 | ethnic_groups = 90.0% [[Jamaicans of African descent|Black]],
1.5% [[Indo-Jamaican|East Indian]],
0.4% [[White people|White]],
7.3% [[Multiracial]] | additional_info = }} [[File:JamaicaOMC.png|thumb|500px|Jamaica's parishes, main rivers and main centres]] [[Jamaica]] lies {{convert|90|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}} south of [[Cuba]] and {{convert|118|mi|km|order=flip|abbr=on}} west of [[Haiti]]. At its greatest extent, Jamaica is {{convert|146|mi|km|abbr=on|order=flip}} long, and its width varies between {{convert|34|and|84|km|mi|abbr=on}}. With an area of {{convert|10,911|km2|abbr=on}}, Jamaica is the largest island of the [[Commonwealth Caribbean]] and the third largest of the [[Greater Antilles]], after [[Cuba]] and [[Hispaniola]]. Many small islands are located along the south coast of Jamaica, such as the [[Port Royal Cays]]. Southwest of mainland Jamaica lies [[Pedro Bank]], an area of shallow seas, with a number of [[cay]]s (low islands or reefs), extending generally east to west for over {{convert|160|km|abbr=on}}. To the southeast lies Morant Bank, with the [[Morant Cays]], {{convert|51|km|mi|abbr=on}} from [[Morant Point]], the easternmost point of mainland Jamaica. [[Alice Shoal]], {{convert|260|km|abbr=on}} southwest of the main island of Jamaica, falls within the Jamaica–Colombia Joint Regime. ==Geology and landforms== {{main|Geology of Jamaica}} Jamaica and the other islands of the Antilles evolved from an arc of ancient volcanoes that rose from the sea millions of years ago. During periods of submersion, thick layers of limestone were laid down over the old igneous and metamorphic rock. In many places, the limestone is thousands of feet{{Specify|date=March 2012}} thick. The country can be divided into three landform regions: the central mountain chain formed by igneous and metamorphic rocks; the karst limestone hills in the Cockpit area; the low-lying coastal plains and interior valleys.{{Cite web|url=http://fiwiroots.com/terrain.html|title=Jamaica Terrain, Features, Size and Population - Fiwi Roots|website=fiwiroots.com|access-date=2016-04-04}} The highest area is the [[Blue Mountains (Jamaica)|Blue Mountains]] range. These eastern mountains are formed by a central ridge of metamorphic rock running northwest to southeast from which many long spurs jut to the north and south. For a distance of over {{convert|3|km|mi}}, the crest of the ridge exceeds {{convert|1800|m|ft}}. The highest point is [[Blue Mountain Peak]] at {{convert|7402|ft|m|order=flip}}. The Blue Mountains rise to these elevations from the coastal plain in the space of about {{convert|16|km|mi}}, thus producing one of the steepest general gradients in the world. In this part of the country, the old metamorphic rock reveals itself through the surrounding limestone. To the north of the Blue Mountains lies the strongly tilted [[limestone]] plateau forming the [[John Crow Mountains]]. This range rises to elevations of over {{convert|1000|m|ft}}. To the west, in the central part of the country, are two high rolling plateaus: the [[Dry Harbour Mountains]] to the north and the Manchester Plateau to the south. Between the two, the land is rugged and here, also, the limestone layers are broken by the older rocks. Streams that rise in the region flow outward and sink soon after reaching the limestone layers. The limestone plateau covers two-thirds of the country, so that [[karst]] formations dominate the island. Karst is formed by the erosion of the limestone in solution. Sinkholes, caves and caverns, disappearing streams, hummocky hills, and terra rosa (residual red) soils in the valleys are distinguishing features of a karst landscape; all these are present in Jamaica. To the west of the mountains is the rugged terrain of the [[Cockpit Country]], one of the world's most dramatic examples of karst topography. The Cockpit Country is pockmarked with steep-sided hollows, as much as {{convert|120|m|ft}} deep in places, which are separated by conical hills and ridges. On the north, the main defining feature is the fault-based "Escarpment", a long ridge that extends from Flagstaff in the west, through Windsor in the centre, to Campbells and the start of the Barbecue Bottom Road (B10). The Barbecue Bottom Road, which runs north-south, high along the side of a deep, fault-based valley in the east, is the only drivable route across the [[Cockpit Country]]. However, there are two old, historical trails that cross further west, the Troy Trail, and the Quick Step Trail, both of which are seldom used {{As of|2006|lc=y}} and difficult to find. In the southwest, near Quick Step, is the district known as the "Land of Look Behind," so named because Spanish horsemen venturing into this region of hostile runaway slaves were said to have ridden two to a mount, one rider facing to the rear to keep a precautionary watch. Where the ridges between sinkholes in the plateau area have dissolved, flat-bottomed basins or valleys have been formed that are filled with terra rosa soils, some of the most productive on the island. The largest basin is the Vale of Clarendon, {{convert|80|km|mi|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|32|km|mi|abbr=on}} wide. Queen of Spains Valley, [[Nassau Valley]], and Cave Valley were formed by the same process. ==Coasts== The coastline of Jamaica is one of many contrasts. The northeast shore is severely eroded by the ocean. There are many small inlets in the rugged coastline, but no coastal plain of any extent. A narrow strip of plains along the northern coast offers calm seas and white sand beaches. Behind the beaches is a flat raised plain of uplifted coral reef. The southern coast has small stretches of plains lined by black sand beaches. These are backed by cliffs of limestone where the plateaus end. In many stretches with no coastal plain, the cliffs drop {{convert|300|m|ft}} straight to the sea. In the southwest, broad plains stretch inland for a number of kilometres. The [[Black River (Jamaica)|Black River]] courses {{convert|70|km|mi}} through the largest of these plains. The swamplands of the Great Morass and the Upper Morass fill much of the plains. The western coastline contains the island's finest beaches. ==Climate== {{climate chart|[[Kingston, Jamaica|Kingston]] |21|30|19 |21|30|19 |22|30|20 |23|31|30 |24|32|100 |24|32|74 |24|33|42 |24|33|98 |24|32|114 |23|32|177 |23|31|65 |22|31|47 |float=left |source=[http://www.metservice.gov.jm/documents/Mean_Climatological_Data.pdf Meteorological Service, Jamaica] }} Two types of climate are found in Jamaica. An upland tropical climate prevails on the windward side of the mountains, whereas a semiarid climate predominates on the leeward side. Warm trade winds from the east and northeast bring rainfall throughout the year. The rainfall is heaviest from May to October, with peaks in those two months. The average rainfall is {{convert|1960|mm|in|1}} per year. Rainfall is much greater in the mountain areas facing the north and east, however. Where the higher elevations of the John Crow Mountains and the Blue Mountains catch the rain from the moisture-laden winds, rainfall exceeds {{convert|5080|mm|in|0}} per year. Since the southwestern half of the island lies in the rain shadow of the mountains, it has a semiarid climate and receives fewer than {{convert|760|mm|in|1}} of rainfall annually. Temperatures in Jamaica are fairly constant throughout the year, averaging {{convert|25|to|30|°C|°F}} in the lowlands and {{convert|15|to|22|°C|°F|1}} at higher elevations. Temperatures may dip to below {{convert|10|°C}} at the peaks of the Blue Mountains. The island receives, in addition to the northeast trade winds, refreshing onshore breezes during the day and cooling offshore breezes at night. These are known on Jamaica as the "Doctor Breeze" and the "Undertaker's Breeze," respectively. Jamaica lies in the Atlantic [[hurricane belt]]; as a result, the island sometimes experiences significant storm damage. Powerful hurricanes which have hit the island directly causing death and destruction include [[Hurricane Charlie (1951)|Hurricane Charlie]] in 1951 and [[Hurricane Gilbert]] in 1988. Several other powerful hurricanes have passed near to the island with damaging effects. In 1980, for example, [[Hurricane Allen]] destroyed nearly all Jamaica's banana crop. [[Hurricane Ivan]] (2004) swept past the island causing heavy damage and a number of deaths; in 2005, Hurricanes [[Hurricane Dennis|Dennis]] and [[Hurricane Emily (2005)|Emily]] brought heavy rains to the island. A Category 4 hurricane, [[Hurricane Dean]], caused some deaths and heavy damage to Jamaica in August 2007. The [[Pre-1600 Atlantic hurricane seasons|first recorded]] hurricane to hit Jamaica was in 1519. The island has been struck by tropical cyclones regularly. During two of the coldest periods in the last 250 years (1780s and 1810s), the frequency of hurricanes in the Jamaica region was unusually high. Another peak of activity occurred in the 1910s, the coldest decade of the 20th century. On the other hand, hurricane formation was greatly diminished from 1968 to 1994, which for some reason coincides with the great [[Sahel drought]].{{cite book |title=The 18th century climate of Jamaica derived from the journals of [[Thomas Thistlewood]], 1750-1786 |last=Chenoweth |first=Michael |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2003 |series=Transactions of the American Philosophical Society |volume=93 |publisher=American Philosophical Society |location=Philadelphia |isbn=0-87169-932-X |pages= }} ==Vegetation and wildlife== {{expand section|date=July 2014}} Although most of Jamaica's native vegetation has been stripped in order to make room for cultivation, some areas have been left virtually undisturbed since the time of [[Christopher Columbus|Columbus]]. Indigenous vegetation can be found along the northern coast from Rio Bueno to [[Discovery Bay, Jamaica|Discovery Bay]], in the highest parts of the Blue Mountains, and in the heart of the Cockpit Country. As in the case of vegetation, considerable loss of wildlife has occurred beginning with the settlement of native peoples in the region millennia ago. For example, the only [[pinniped]] ever known to the Caribbean, the [[Caribbean monk seal]] once occurred in Jamaican waters and has now been driven to [[extinction]].Peter Saundry. 2010. [http://www.eoearth.org/article/Caribbean_monk_seal ''Caribbean monk seal''. Encyclopedia of Earth] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100814162030/http://www.eoearth.org/article/Caribbean_monk_seal |date=August 14, 2010 }}. eds. C. Michael Hogan and Cutler Cleveland. National council for Science and the Environment, Washington DC Mongoose ([[Herpestes auropunctatus]]), introduced to Jamaica in 1872 to reduce rat populations that damaged commercial sugarcane ([[Saccharum officinarum]]) crops{{Cite journal|last=Lewis|first=C.B.|date=November 1953|title=Rats and the Mongoose in Jamaica|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/oryx/article/rats-and-the-mongoose-in-jamaica/D56A52D4B641F393043702CD16CA107B|journal=Oryx|volume=2|pages=170-172|via=}}, prey on several Jamaican species, including the critically endangered, Jamaican iguana ([[Cyclura collei]]), and have been implicated in the historical population declines and extinctions of many others{{Cite journal|last=Lewis et al.|first=D.S.|date=May 2010|title=Conservation implications of small Indian mongoose (Herpestes auropunctatus) predation in a hotspot within a hotspot: the Hellshire Hills, Jamaica|url=https://s3.amazonaws.com/academia.edu.documents/39477878/Conservation_implications_of_small_India20151027-4103-2g325f.pdf?AWSAccessKeyId=AKIAIWOWYYGZ2Y53UL3A&Expires=1521751529&Signature=Rk4G29LjTU4tfbqDOIzhF3DT%2FHY%3D&response-content-disposition=inline%3B%20filename%3DConservation_implications_of_small_India.pdf|journal=Biological Invasions|volume=13|pages=25-33|via=}}. Other wildlife species inhabiting the island include, the West Indian Manatee ([[Trichechus manatus]]), American crocodile ([[Crocodylus acutus]]), and the endemic Homerus Swallowtail ([[Papilio homerus]]),which is the largest butterfly species in the Western Hemisphere{{Cite journal|last=Lehnert|first=Matthew S.|date=2008|title=The population biology and ecology of the Homerus swallowtail, Papilio (Pterourus) homerus, in the Cockpit Country, Jamaica|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Matthew_Lehnert/publication/227006546_The_population_biology_and_ecology_of_the_Homerus_swallowtail_Papilio_Pterourus_homerus_in_the_Cockpit_Country_Jamaica/links/0c96052a0f34822514000000/The-population-biology-and-ecology-of-the-Homerus-swallowtail-Papilio-Pterourus-homerus-in-the-Cockpit-Country-Jamaica.pdf|journal=Journal of Insect Conservation|volume=12|pages=179-188|via=}}. ==See also== * [[Jamaica]] * [[List of cities and towns in Jamaica]] ==References== {{commons category|Geography of Jamaica}} {{Reflist}} *{{loc}} *{{CIA World Factbook}} {{Geography of North America}} {{North America topic|Climate of}} {{Geography of Jamaica}} {{Jamaica topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Geography Of Jamica}} [[Category:Geography of Jamaica| ]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2014}} [[File:Reygersdal netball.jpg|thumb|225px|Schoolyard netball game at Reygersdal Primary School, South Africa.|alt=Coloured girls playing netball on an outside court]] '''[[Netball]]''' is a popular participant sport in some parts of the world, particularly in countries of the [[Commonwealth of Nations]].<ref name=Thompson-258>{{harvnb|Thompson|2006|p=258}}</ref><ref name=dofaat-2008a>{{harvnb|Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade|2008a}}</ref> According to the IFNA, over 20 million people play netball in more than 72 countries.<ref name=Thompson-258 /><ref name=IFNA-History>{{Cite web |author=International Federation of Netball Associations |title=About IFNA |url=http://www.netball.org/ifna.aspx |accessdate=7 March 2011 |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110308132327/http://www.netball.org/IFNA.aspx |archivedate=8 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> IFNA member nations are divided into five regional groups: Africa, America, Asia, Europe and Oceania.<ref name=Shakespear-xii>{{harvnb|Shakespear|Caldow|2009|p=xii}}</ref>
==Africa== {{main|Netball in Africa}} Netball is a popular women's sport in parts of Africa.<ref name=DaCosta-217>{{harvnb|DaCosta|Miragaya|2002|p=217}}</ref><ref name=Shakespear-xi>{{harvnb|Shakespear|Caldow|2009|p=xi}}</ref> Several African nations are ranked amongst the top twenty-five in the world. As of August 2015, [[South Africa]] was ranked number five, [[Malawi]] was ranked number six, [[Uganda]] was ranked thirteen, [[Zambia]] was ranked seventeen, [[Botswana]] was ranked nineteen in the world.<ref name="International Netball Federation">{{cite web |author=International Netball Federation |title=Current World Rankings |url=http://www.netball.org/thrilling-world-class-events/current-world-rankings}} Last updated 16 August 2015.</ref> <!--Need to work COSANA in here-->
In [[Netball in South Africa|South Africa]] participation rates are high, with 40% of African girls rating netball as their favourite sport in 2002,<ref name=Keim-85>{{harvnb|Keim|2003|p=85}}</ref><ref name=Britton-107>{{harvnb|Britton|Fish|Meintjes|2009|p=107}}</ref> although many African girls claiming netball as their favourite sport had never played it.<ref name=Keim-143>{{harvnb|Keim|2003|p=143}}</ref> South Africa was part of the 1960 meeting of Commonwealth countries in [[Sri Lanka]] that standardised the rules for the game.<ref name="ifna-2008"/> From 1969 to 1994, South Africa was expelled from competing internationally in netball due to its [[South Africa under apartheid|apartheid policies]].<ref name=Keim-33>{{harvnb|Keim|2003|p=33}}</ref><ref name=Booth-99>{{harvnb|Booth|1998|p=99}}</ref><ref name=nnz-2009>{{harvnb|Netball New Zealand|2009}}</ref> During the [[1995 Netball World Championships]] South Africa scored an upset win over New Zealand in pool play and finished second behind Australia.<ref name=nnz-2009/> In 2000, New Zealand's national side toured South Africa for the first time, playing three test matches. In 2001, a Tri-Nations Series was launched between Australia, New Zealand and South Africa, which was also won by New Zealand.<ref name=nnz-2009/>
[[File:Malawi netball girls.jpg|thumb|left|A local netball match in Malawi.|alt=Malawian young women playing netball on a dirt court. One player is preparing to shoot for goal, while other players in and around the shooting circle look on. Bibs are not worn by any of the players.]] Netball is the most popular women's sport in [[Netball in Botswana|Botswana]], Malawi<ref name="Shakespear-xi"/> and [[Netball in Tanzania|Tanzania]].<ref name=Massoa-119>{{harvnb|Massoa|Fasting|2002|p=119}}</ref> In [[Netball in Botswana|Botswana]] netball is primarily played by women,<ref name=BNSC-2011>{{harvnb|BNSC|2011}}</ref> with men traditionally serving as officials, coaches and administrators for the sport. There are also a few men-only teams, although many were discontinued in the 2000s in favour of mixed-gender teams.<ref name=BNSC-2011/> The Botswana Netball Association as founded in the 1970s and is the national organisation responsible for netball in Botswana.<ref name=BNSC-2011/> Netball was introduced to Tanzania after World War I, when the country was under [[Great Britain|British]] colonial rule. All primary schools in the country have a court and children are generally recruited to high level teams at a young age.<ref name=Massoa-121>{{harvnb|Massoa|Fasting|2002|p=121}}</ref> The Netball Association of Tanzania (CHANETA) was created in 1966 and has been mostly run by women, although men can play a role in coaching.<ref name=Massoa-119/> During the 1970s and 1980s, the [[International Olympic Committee]] and the [[British Council]] promoted netball in Tanzania,<ref name=Massoa-120>{{harvnb|Massoa|Fasting|2002|p=120}}</ref> but were unwilling to investment money.<ref name=Massoa-120 /> Economic liberalisation saw the popularity of netball decline during the 1990s, and recent attempts to raise netball's popularity have been slow as sport is culturally more acceptable for men.<ref name="Massoa-121"/> The Tanzanian national netball team finished in third place at the 2010 Nations Cup.<ref name="nsingapore-2010"/>
==Americas== {{main|Netball in the Americas}}
[[File:Netball in Jamaica.jpg|thumb|225px|right|Netball being played in Jamaica.|alt=Two netball teams huddled together on an outside netball court. The court is lit by lights as it is twilight.]] The IFNA covers 54 nations within the Americas, 13 of which have their own national governing bodies.<ref name=ifna-2010f>{{harvnb|International Federation of Netball Associations|2010f}}</ref> Each year, the region hosts two tournaments: the CNA U16 Championship and the AFNA Senior Championship.<ref name=ifna-2010f/> Netball is most popular in Commonwealth countries,<ref name="Thompson-258"/> such as [[Antigua and Barbuda]] and [[Grenada]].<ref name=Epstein-8>{{harvnb|Epstein|2007|p=8}}</ref><ref name=Epstein-171>{{harvnb|Epstein|2007|p=171}}</ref> As of August 2015, several teams in the region ranked amongst the top 25 in the world, including Jamaica (4th), Trinidad & Tobago (9th) Barbados (11th), Saint Lucia (18th), Canada (21st), and the United States of America (25th).<ref name="International Netball Federation"/> [[File:Netball being played at Madison Square Garden.jpeg|thumb|Netball being played in front of 14,000 at Madison Square Garden]]
Netball has been played in [[Jamaica]] since 1909,<ref name=JNA-History>{{Cite web |author=Jamaica Netball Association |title=The History of Netball |url=http://jamaicanetball.org.jm/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5&Itemid=74 |accessdate=13 March 2011 |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110318105216/http://www.jamaicanetball.org.jm/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=5&Itemid=74 |archivedate=18 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> mostly at schools and teachers' training colleges.<ref name=JNA-History/> Once graduated, players created club sides for casual play, expanding the game throughout the country.<ref name=JNA-History/> During the 1930s, the major national competition was the ISSA Cup with seven teams. One of the teams, Wolmer's Old Girls Association (W.O.G.A.), built the first hard netball court in Jamaica.<ref name=JNA-History/> Pancho Rankine, Margaret Beckford and Margarietta St. Juste created the Jamaica Netball Association in 1959 and the organisation became affiliated to the West Indies Netball Board. They formed a national team to compete in the West Indies Tournament that was held in [[Montserrat]] in August 1959. In 1960, a member of the All England Netball Association went to Jamaica to coach, lecture and test umpires.<ref name=aena-18>{{harvnb|All England Netball Association|1976|p=18}}</ref> Two years later, an English team toured the West Indies, beating Jamaica, Trinidad and the West Indies.<ref name="aena-18"/> In 1967, a team representing Greater London toured Jamaica, winning all their matches on the tour.<ref name=aena-20>{{harvnb|All England Netball Association|1976|p=20}}</ref> In 1970, a team of British Students toured the Bahamas and Jamaica. Later that year, Jamaica's national team toured England.<ref name=aena-22>{{harvnb|All England Netball Association|1976|p=22}}</ref> The third World Tournament was held in Kingston, Jamaica in 1971.<ref name="aena-22"/> Jamaica's national association protested against South Africa's apartheid policies, banning players who participated in the 1973 English tour of South Africa.<ref name=uncaa-ccvii>{{harvnb|United Nations Centre Against Apartheid|1976|p=ccvii}}</ref>
Netball's popularity in the United States increased during the 1970s, particularly in the New York area. In 1992 the first national championship was held and in 1995 the USA's first international game was played against England at the Netball World Championship in Birmingham.<ref name=USNA-2010b>{{harvnb|United States of America Netball Association (USANA), Inc.|2010b}}</ref> In 2003, the country was ranked 9th in the world,<ref name=USANA-2010a>{{harvnb|United States of America Netball Association (USANA), Inc.|2010a}}</ref> however in 2015 the country is ranked 25th in the world.<ref name=ifna-ranking>{{harvnb|International Federation of Netball Associations|2011a}}</ref> Canada has both men's and women's national teams.<ref name=Tagg-411>{{harvnb|Tagg|2008|p=411}}</ref>
In 2007, [[Netball America]], now the largest Netball Association in the USA, was founded by Steve Anderson, Moreen Logsdon, Jo O'Key, and Sonya Ottaway. Netball America is sanctioned by the United States [[International University Sports Federation]] to host the 2nd World University Netball Championship in Miami 2016. Netball America also sent the first team of American Citizens to the inaugural World University Netball Championship in South Africa in 2012. The Netball America University Team is currently ranked 8th in the World.<ref>http://www.netballamerica.com/about-us/who-we-are/</ref> Twelve nations will be competing at the 2016 FISU World University Netball Championship in Miami, Florida.<ref>http://worlduninetball.com/</ref> Netball America is the leader in bringing Netball to the USA and has seen the introduction of Netball into US educational systems (New York City, Florida, New Hampshire, Tampa and Miami) and also has introduced Netball across 33 US States. In addition to being the host for the World University Netball Championship, Netball America is also the host of the Disney International Youth Tournament and the World Out Games that will have 17,000 athletes descend upon Miami in May 2017, and Netball America petitioned to get Netball included as a new sport to the games that support the LGBT community<ref>http://www.NetballAmerica.com</ref>
<!--Need more info about Canada-->
==Asia== {{Main|Netball in Asia}} [[File:Mixed netball Brisbane.jpg|thumb|220px|Local mixed netball game in Brisbane, Queensland.|left|alt=Woman holding a netball while other players stand watching her. Woman and shooting team is wearing white with red bibs. Opposing team is wearing blue with green bibs.]] Netball is popular in several parts of Asia.<ref name=sri-lanka>{{harvnb|Government of Sri Lanka|2001}}</ref><ref name=Ng-2010>{{harvnb|Ng|2010}}</ref><ref name=lanka-journal>{{harvnb|Lanka Journal|2009}}</ref><ref name=lanka-truth>{{harvnb|Lanka Truth|2009}}</ref> The IFNA Asia region includes countries such as Australia (geopolitically considered part of Oceania), India, Malaysia, Singapore and Sri Lanka.<ref name=ifna-2011c>{{harvnb|International Federation of Netball Associations|2011c}}</ref> The major regional competition is the [[Asian Netball Championship]].<ref name="sri-lanka"/><ref name=Ng-2010>{{harvnb|Ng|2010}}</ref><ref name="lanka-journal"/><ref name="lanka-truth"/> In 1994, the first Asian Youth Championship was held in Hong Kong.<ref name="nsing-2011b"/>
[[File:BKP Netball Brunei.jpg|thumb|200px|upright|BKP Netball Tournament at the SHHB Sports Complex in Berakas, Brunei (May 2009).|right|alt=Adult women from Brunei playing netball. One team is wearing green and the other team is wearing yellow. The game is being played indoors on wooden floors. The players are all wearing pants. Some have coverings over their heads. The yellow team is in act of shooting and the green team is trying to block the shot.]] Netball has the highest participation rate of any team sport—male or female—in [[Netball in Australia|Australia]],<ref name=PofNSW-11179>{{harvnb|Parliament of New South Wales|2004|p=11179}}</ref><ref name=Taylor-6>{{harvnb|Taylor|1998|p=6}}</ref><ref name=Bottenburg-214>{{harvnb|Van Bottenburg|2001|p=214}}</ref><ref name=DaCosta-66>{{harvnb|DaCosta|Miragaya|2002|p=66}}</ref> but it is not a large spectator following.<ref name=DaCosta-37>{{harvnb|DaCosta|Miragaya|2002|p=37}}</ref> In 2005 and 2006, netball was the 10th most popular spectator sport for women after tennis.<ref name=ABS-2007>{{harvnb|Australian Bureau of Statistics|2007}}</ref> Netball was brought to Australia by English school teachers, with a team having been organised by 1904 at Parramatta Superior Schools.<ref name="PofNSW-11179"/> In 1927, a national federation for the sport, Australian Women's Basketball Association, was created.<ref name="PofNSW-11179"/> Australia's national team toured England in 1957,<ref name=ifna-2008>{{harvnb|International Federation of Netball Associations|2008}}</ref> which resulted in a number of Commonwealth countries organising a meeting to try to standardise the rules of the game.<ref name=ifna-2008/>
In Australia 80% of netball is played at netball clubs,<ref name="DaCosta-66"/> although the number of netball clubs around Australia has been in decline since the 1940s.<ref name=Atherly-352>{{harvnb|Atherly|2006|p=352}}</ref> Currently <!-- as of ????--> there are around 350,000 registered players and over 1.2 million total players in the country.<ref name=Turk-men>{{harvnb|Turk}}</ref> Prior to the establishment of the ANZ Championship, the [[National Netball League]] was the major competition in Australia.<ref name=Davis-4>{{harvnb|Davis|Davis|2006|p=4}}</ref> It included teams from the [[Australian Capital Territory]], [[New South Wales]], [[Queensland]], [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]], [[South Australia]] and [[Western Australia]].<ref name=Davis-4/> The [[Australian national netball team]] won the first world championships in 1963 in England,<ref name=spot-ball>{{harvnb|Australian Women's Weekly|1979}}</ref> and nine of the twelve Netball World Championships to date. As of August 2015, the national team is ranked first on the [[INF World Rankings]].<ref name="International Netball Federation"/> The country set an attendance record for a netball match with a crowd of 14,339 at the Australia – New Zealand Netball [[Test match (netball)|Test]] held at the [[Sydney SuperDome]] game in 2004.<ref name=department-2008>{{harvnb|Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade|2008}}</ref>
Women started playing netball in [[Netball in India|India]] as early as 1926.<ref name=sagar-2010/> The [[Sports Authority of India]] and the Government of India has provided funded for the country's youth national team.<ref name=sagar-2010>{{harvnb|Sagar|2010}}</ref> In 2001 India's national team competed in the fifth Asian Netball Championship in Colombo, Sri Lanka.<ref name=sri-lanka/> Important netball competitions held in India include the [[2010 Commonwealth Games]],<ref name=ifna-2008/> and the 7th Asian Youth Netball Championship.<ref name=sagar-2010/> The Indian national netball team's best results have been placing sixth at the 2010 Nations Cup<ref name=nsingapore-2010>{{harvnb|Netball Singapore|2010a}}</ref> and fourth at the 2010 Asian Youth Netball Championship.<ref name="nsing-2011b"/>
[[File:Interbatch Games 2009.jpg|thumb|220px|Men's Interbatch Games 2009 RMSA in Malaysia.|right|alt=High school or university aged men playing netball on an indoor court. Floor is painted wood. Gym has a window behind the basket.]] Netball is the most popular women's sport in [[Netball in Malaysia|Malaysia]].<ref name=NetballAsia-2011>{{harvnb|Netball Asia|2011}}</ref> The national organisation, the [[Malaysian Netball Association]], was created in 1978 and the sport is part of the national curriculum beginning at year 3.<ref name=NetballAsia-2011/> In 1998, 113 districts held netball competitions,<ref name=DaCosta-88>{{harvnb|DaCosta|Miragaya|2002|p=88}}</ref> and there were 1,718 registered netball teams in the country.<ref name=DaCosta-88 /> In 2001, netball was sufficiently popular in South East Asia for it to be included in the 21st [[Southeast Asian Games]] in [[Kuala Lumpur]].<ref name="nsing-2011b"/> Malaysia had a national team compete in the fifth Asian Netball Championship in Colombo in 2001.<ref name=sri-lanka/> As of August 2015, the women's national team was ranked number twenty-two in the world.<ref name="International Netball Federation"/>
[[Netball Singapore]] is the official governing body for the sport in [[Netball in Singapore|Singapore]].<ref name=NS-body>{{harvnb|Netball Singapore|2011}}</ref> It was created in 1962, with 63 registered clubs and now governs 80,000 netball players.<ref name="NS-body"/> The national team competed in its first major tournament in 1967 at the [[Netball World Championships]]<ref name="nsing-2011b"/> and sent a team to the fifth Asian Netball Championship in [[Colombo]].<ref name=sri-lanka/> As of August 2015, the women's national team was ranked number fifteen in the world.<ref name="International Netball Federation"/>
Netball was first played in [[Netball in Sri Lanka|Sri Lanka]] by Ceylon Girl Guide Company at Kandy High School in 1921.<ref name=lanka-2010>{{Cite web |author=Sri Lanka Netball |title=The History Of Netball In Sri Lanka |url=http://www.slnetball.com/History.html |date=30 September 2010 |accessdate=3 March 2011 |ref=harv |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110306080932/http://www.slnetball.com/History.html |archivedate=6 March 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> In 1927, netball was played at a Government Training College for the first time, helping to spread the game around Sri Lanka.<ref name=lanka-2010/> By 1952, Sri Lankan clubs were playing Indian club sides.<ref name=lanka-2010/> In 1956, Sri Lanka played its first international match against Australia's national team in Sri Lanka.<ref name=lanka-2010/> The 1960 netball meeting of Commonwealth countries to try to standardise the rules for the game took place in Sri Lanka.<ref name=ifna-2008/> The Netball Federation of Sri Lanka was created in 1972, before being dissolved by the government in 1983.<ref name=lanka-2010/> Sri Lanka had a national team compete in the fifth Asian Netball Championship held in [[Colombo]]. As of August 2015, the women's national team was ranked number twenty-four in the world.<ref name="International Netball Federation"/>
==Europe== {{Main|Netball in Europe}} [[File:Orkney v Shetland netball 2009.jpg|thumb|300px|Orkney A (red) v Shetland A (white/blue): intercounty netball (March 2009) in Scotland.|right|alt=Netball players in centre third of court. One player in red has caught the ball and two players in white are moving towards her.]] Netball is primarily played in Commonwealth countries, which were heavily involved in standardising the rules for netball.<ref name=ifna-2008/> The Federation of European Netball Associations (FENA), sometimes referred to as Netball Europe, is the governing body for netball in the Europe netball region. The organisation was created in 1989/1990.<ref name=netball-europe>{{harvnb|England Netball|2010}}</ref> As of August 2015, the English women's national team was ranked number three in the world, Wales is ranked number eight, Scotland is ranked number ten, and Northern Ireland is ranked number twelve.<ref name="International Netball Federation"/> The major netball competition in Europe is the [[Netball Superleague]]<ref name=fiat-netball>{{harvnb|FIAT Netball Superleague}}</ref> and features nine to ten teams from all areas of Britain.<ref name=fiat-netball/>
In the United Kingdom, netball has traditionally been managed by women.<ref name=White-46>{{harvnb|White|2002|p=46}}</ref> In [[Netball in England|England]], netball is included as part of the physical education curriculum.<ref name=White-37>{{harvnb|White|2002|p=37}}</ref> Its inclusion had been at times controversial; during the 1910s and 1920s, schools worried about the potential negative impact of physical exercise on the health of girls.<ref name=games-for-girls>{{harvnb|Western Argus|1922}}</ref> The [[Welsh Netball Association]] (Cymdeithas Pêl Rwyd Cymru) was created in 1945.<ref name=ifna-wales>{{harvnb|International Federation of Netball Associations|2011}}</ref> The WNA is responsible for national championships, [[Wales national netball team|Welsh squad]] selection, international matches, the training and development of players, coaches, and umpires and for the [[Sport Wales National Centre]] Netball Academy, [[Cardiff]].<ref name=wna-wales>{{harvnb|Welsh Netball Association|2009}}</ref> The Welsh Netball Association is based in [[Pontcanna]], Cardiff.<ref name=wna-wales/> Like other national associations, the Welsh have created a modified version of the game for children called "Dragon Netball".<ref name=ifna-wales/> The rate of comparative participation for netball to other sports differs from key-stage to key-stage (year levels in school) in Northern Ireland.<ref name=Mahoney-109>{{harvnb|Mahoney|1997|p=109}}</ref> In Northern Ireland, about 1,300 women play competitive netball in club-based leagues.<ref name=Mahoney-103>{{harvnb|Mahoney|1997|p=103}}</ref>
==Oceania== {{Main|Netball in Oceania}} In Australia<ref name=dofaat-2008a/> and New Zealand, netball is one of the most popular sports played by women.<ref name=Davis-5>{{harvnb|Davis|Davis|2006|p=5}}</ref><ref name=abos>{{harvnb|Australian Bureau of Statistics|2006}}</ref><ref name=jock>{{harvnb|Phillips|2011}}</ref><!--Australia reference included because the country is regionally important in terms of development of the game.!--> Women's sport in Oceania has traditionally had a very low profile.<ref name=Brawley-119>{{harvnb|Brawley|1997|p=119}}</ref> Despite this, netball is popular in Oceania, with its growth partly because of New Zealand encouraging the game and providing money for the training of coaches, umpires and other netball development needs.<ref name=Lal-258>{{harvnb|Lal|Fortune|2000|p=458}}</ref> Netball is one of the sports at the [[Pacific Games]], a multi-sport event, with participation from countries around the South Pacific, that is held every four years.<ref name=mckinnon-51>{{harvnb|McKinnon|2009|p=51}}</ref> The popularity of netball is growing amongst men on the island countries in Oceania, because sport is an important way for villages to keep in touch with each other.<ref name=mckinnon-51/> The game's popularity can also be seen in local languages, where local words have been created to describe it.<ref name=Sperlich-488>{{harvnb|Sperlich|1997|p=488}}</ref> The [[Oceania Netball Federation]] (ONF) is the governing body for netball in the Oceania region.<ref name=ifna-2011e>{{harvnb|International Federation of Netball Associations|2011e}}</ref>
In [[Netball in New Zealand|New Zealand]], netball is the most popular women's participation sport. In 1984, there were 114,210 players<ref name="Bottenburg-214"/> and currently there are over 11,000 teams and 120,440 players.<ref name=Thompson-258 /> The only sport with more players is golf, which has 128,860 male and female players.<ref name=Thompson-258 /> Ninety-eight percent of New Zealand netball players are female.<ref name=Bottenburg-169>{{harvnb|Van Bottenburg|2001|p=169}}</ref> The sports with the next highest rates of female participation are [[field hockey]] and [[horse racing]], both at sixty-four percent.<ref name=Bottenburg-170>{{harvnb|Van Bottenburg|2001|p=170}}</ref> Netball is extremely popular amongst [[Māori people|Māori]] women, who are more active in sport in general than their white counterparts.<ref name=Thompson-257>{{harvnb|Thompson|2002|p=257}}</ref> New Zealand took part in the 1960 netball meeting of [[Commonwealth of Nations|Commonwealth countries]] to try to standardise the rules for the game.<ref name=ifna-2008/> New Zealand has a history of netball being a spectator sport with the games being televised on [[Television New Zealand]].<ref name=Thompson-258 /> The 1999 Netball World Championships final between Australia and New Zealand was the highest rated program ever on New Zealand television.<ref name=Thompson-258 /> New Zealand also has a men's national team that has competed in the 2009 and 2011 International Challenge Men's and Mixed Netball Tournament.<ref name=samoa-men/> As of August 2015, the women's national team was ranked number two in the world.<ref name="International Netball Federation"/>
[[File:Natalei netball.jpg|thumb|300px|A netball competition at Natalei, Fiji.|right|alt=An outdoor netball game taking place in Fiji. The game is being played on grass. The players are either high school age or adults. Both teams are wearing blue netball uniforms. The team in the darker blue is in the act of passing the ball.]] The [[Netball in the Cook Islands|Cook Islands]] are a major netball playing country in Oceania,<ref name="nsing-2011b">{{harvnb|Netball Singapore|2011b}}</ref> with over 1,000 registered members.<ref name=cina-2009>{{harvnb|Cook Islands Netball Association|2009}}</ref> The game became popular during the 1970s,<ref name="Lal-258"/> and is an important sport in the region.<ref name=Crocombe-13>{{harvnb|Crocombe|1990|p=13}}</ref> The country has participated at several international events including the [[Pacific Games]],<ref name=Crocombe-13/> the [[Commonwealth Games]],<ref name=Crocombe-54>{{harvnb|Crocombe|1990|p=54}}</ref> the Netball World Championships,<ref name="Crocombe-54"/> the [[World Games]],<ref name=Crocombe-13/> the Oceania Netball Tournament,<ref name=Crocombe-13/> the [[World Youth Netball Championship]],<ref name="nsing-2011b"/> and the International Challenge Men's and Mixed Netball Tournament.<ref name=samoa-men>{{harvnb|Samoa Observer|2011}}</ref> Netball has a lot of grass roots support and is an important part of life for many women on the islands.<ref name=Alexeyeff-45>{{harvnb|Alexeyeff|2009|p=145}}</ref><ref name=Alexeyeff-85>{{harvnb|Alexeyeff|2009|p=85}}</ref> The sport's popularity is partly due to the influence of New Zealand, where Cook Island players have competed for New Zealand's national team. New Zealand worked hard to develop the sport in the country during the 1980s, when they hosted a number of coaching and umpiring clinics.<ref name=Lal-258/> The Cook Islands won the netball competition at the first [[South Pacific Games]] (now Pacific Games), held in 1981.<ref name="Crocombe-13"/> In the 1990 Oceania Netball Tournament, the team beat New Zealand, [[Tonga]] and Fiji to come in second, behind Australia.<ref name="Crocombe-13"/> As of August 2015, the women's national team was ranked number twenty-three in the world.<ref name="International Netball Federation"/>
Women's participation in [[netball in Fiji]] is comparable to men's participation in rugby.<ref name=Starnes-42>{{harvnb|Starnes|Luckham|2009|p=42}}</ref>
The sport started to grow in popularity during the 1970s.<ref name="Lal-258" /> Fiji was supposed to host the 2007 World Netball Championship, but due to a [[2006 Fijian coup d'état|military coup]] the IFNA decided to move the championship to Auckland.<ref name="Starnes-42" /> Netball has a large amount of grassroots support in [[Netball in Samoa|Samoa]]. The sport started to grow in popularity during the 1970s.<ref name="Lal-258" /> Games in Fiji and Samoa are most often played by girls on Saturdays during the winter, though games can be played at all times of the year.<ref name="mckinnon-51" /> Samoa and Fiji are traditional netball rivals, competing against each other at events like the Pacific Games.<ref name="mckinnon-51" /> As of August 2015, Samoa's national team was ranked number fourteen in the world and Fiji's was ranked number seven.<ref name="International Netball Federation"/>

revision.text:
The '''geology of [[Nicaragua]]''' includes [[Paleozoic]] crystalline basement rocks, [[Mesozoic]] intrusive igneous rocks and sedimentary rocks spanning the [[Cretaceous]] to the [[Pleistocene]]. Volcanoes erupted in the [[Paleogene]]and within the last 2.5 million years of the [[Quaternary]], due to the subduction of the Cocos Plate, which drives melting and magma creation. Many of these volcanoes are in the Nicaraguan Depression paralleled by the northwest-trending Middle America Trench which marks the Caribbean-Cocos plate boundary. Almost all the rocks in Nicaragua originated as dominantly [[felsic]] continental crust, unlike other areas in the region which include stranded sections of [[mafic]] oceanic crust. Structural geologists have grouped all the rock units as the Chortis Block.
==Volcanology== Volcanism remains active in Nicaragua. The Masaya Caldera Complex erupted 460,000 and 50,000 years ago with the Las Sierras Formation as a Pliocene-Pleistocene basement rock. Massive pyroclastic and [[ignimbrite]] eruptions caused the caldera to collapse although most of the material it erupted has been basalt. Analysis of an eruption of the caldera in 1772 indicates perhaps the highest rate of lava effusion in Central America.<ref name="osti">{{Cite journal|title=Geology and eruptive mechanisms of Masaya Caldera Complex, Nicaragua (Thesis/Dissertation)|osti = 6676327|date = January 1983|last1 = Williams|first1 = S. N.}}</ref> Another active volcano is the San Cristobal Volcanic Complex in the northwest, which erupted in the 1500s and 1600s and again at a reduced level in 1971, with tholeiitic, calc-alkaline and [[andesite]] material.<ref name="sciencedirect">{{Cite journal|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/0377027387900643|title=Geology of the San Cristobal volcanic complex, Nicaragua|journal=Journal of Volcanology and Geothermal Research|volume=33|pages=223–230|accessdate=2018-11-10|doi=10.1016/0377-0273(87)90064-3|year=1987|last1=Hazlett|first1=Richard W.}}</ref>
==Natural resource geology== Nicaragua has 94 metal deposits and 46 non-metallic deposits. It is the leading gold producer in Central America from deposits in Bonanza, La Libertad and Limon, in epithermal and mesothermal vein deposits, as well as skarn and placer deposits. Eight million ounces of gold have been extracted since 1930. Copper, zinc, silver, limestone, aggregate, clay and gypsum are also important resources.<ref name="tandfonline">{{Cite journal|title=Information for|journal=International Geology Review|volume=42|pages=45–63|doi=10.1080/00206810009465069|year = 2000|last1 = Arengi|first1 = Joseph T.|last2=Hodgson|first2=Glen V.}}</ref>
Between 1943 and 1977, seismic and drilling surveys were done on the Miskito Basin off the eastern shore in search of oil.<ref name="seg">{{Cite journal|title=An Error Occurred Setting Your User Cookie|journal=The Leading Edge|volume=16|issue=12|pages=1799–1806|doi=10.1190/1.1437584|year = 1997|last1 = Muñoz|first1 = Angélica|last2=Baca|first2=Dania|last3=Artiles|first3=Verónica|last4=Duarte|first4=Manuel|last5=Barboza|first5=Guillermo}}</ref><ref name="wiley">{{Cite journal|title=Neotectonic development of western Nicaragua - Weinberg - 1992 - Tectonics|journal=Tectonics|volume=11|issue=5|pages=1010–1017|doi=10.1029/92TC00859|year = 1992|last1 = Weinberg|first1 = Roberto Ferrez}}</ref>
The Momotombo geothermal field was discovered in 1970, 50 kilometers northeast of Managua adjacent to Momotombo Volcano. Thirty three wells were drilled by 1981 with more than 100 megawatts of energy potential.<ref name="datapages">{{Cite journal|url=http://archives.datapages.com/data/specpubs/mineral1/data/a177/a177/0001/0000/0033.htm|website=archives.datapages.com|title=AAPG Datapages/Archives: Geology and Temperature Distribution of Momotombo Geothermal Field, Nicaragua|volume=177|pages=33–54|accessdate=2018-11-10|year=1981|last1=Moore|first1=James L.|last2=Osbun|first2=Erik|last3=Storm|first3=Paul V.}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{North America topic|Geology of}}
[[Category:Geology of Nicaragua| ]] [[Category:Geology by country| Nicaragua]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox waterfall | name = Hemlock Falls | photo = Hemlock Falls.png | photo_width = | photo_caption = | map = USA Georgia | location = [[Rabun County]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]] | coords = {{Coord|34.852517|-83.610917|type:waterbody|display=inline,title}} | elevation = {{convert|2110|ft|abbr=on}} | type = Cascade | height = {{convert|15|ft|abbr=on}} | width = | height_longest = | average_width = | number_drops = | average_flow = | watercourse = Moccasin Creek | world_rank = }} '''Hemlock Falls''' is a [[waterfall]] located in [[Rabun County, Georgia|Rabun County]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]]. It is located in the [[Tallulah Ranger District]] of the [[Chattahoochee National Forest]] on Moccasin Creek. The '''Hemlock Trail''' is about one mile long, beginning at [[Moccasin Creek State Park]] and following an old railroad bed.
==External links== *[http://georgiatrails.com/trails/hemlock.html Hemlock Trail profile on GeorgiaTrails.com] *[http://www.fs.fed.us/conf/ne-ga-waterfalls/hemlock-falls.shtml U.S. Forest Service Website for Hemlock Falls and Hemlock Trail]
[[Category:Waterfalls of Georgia (U.S. state)]] [[Category:Protected areas of Rabun County, Georgia]] [[Category:Chattahoochee-Oconee National Forest]] [[Category:Waterfalls of Rabun County, Georgia]]

revision.text:
The '''Hydropower Sustainability Assessment Protocol''' is a tool that promotes and guides more sustainable [[hydropower]] projects. It is a methodology used to measure the performance of a hydropower project across more than twenty environmental, social, technical and economic topics.
Hydropower projects can have both a positive and a negative environmental and social impact. This is because the construction of a [[dam]], power plant and [[reservoir]] creates certain social and physical changes in the area it effects. The protocol provides a common language to allow governments, [[civil society]], financial institutions and the hydropower sector to talk about and evaluate [[sustainability]] issues.
Assessments are based on objective evidence and the results are presented in a standardised way, to show how new projects are being developed or how existing facilities are performing.
It has been designed to work on projects and facilities anywhere in the world.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hydropower Sustainability - Home|url = http://www.hydrosustainability.org/|website = www.hydrosustainability.org|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Hydropower Sustainability - Protocol Basics|url = http://www.hydrosustainability.org/Protocol.aspx|website = www.hydrosustainability.org|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref>
== Application ==
=== Purpose ===
The Protocol is used by different hydropower stakeholders for different reasons.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hydropower Sustainability - How it can help|url = http://www.hydrosustainability.org/Protocol/How-can-it-help-.aspx|website = www.hydrosustainability.org|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref>
Popular uses include:
* Independent review of sustainability issues * Guiding improvement of sustainability practice * Comparison with international best practice * Communication with stakeholders * Facilitating access to finance * Preparing clients to meet bank requirements * Reducing investment risk
=== Users ===
[[Crédit Agricole]], [[Société Générale|Societe Generale]], [[Standard Chartered]], [[Citigroup|Citi]], and [[UBS]] now refer to the Protocol in their sector guidance.<ref>http://mediacommun.ca-cib.com/sitegenic/medias/DOC/13870/2012-12-politique-sectorielle-rse-energie-hydroelectricite-eng.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.societegenerale.com/sites/default/files/documents/Document%20RSE/Finance%20responsable/Dams%20&%20Hydropower%20Sector%20Policy.pdf</ref><ref>https://www.sc.com/en/resources/global-en/pdf/sustainabilty/Dams_and_Hydropower_Position_Statement.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.citigroup.com/citi/environment/data/1160840_Sector_Brief_HydroPower.pdf</ref><ref>https://www.ubs.com/content/dam/ubs/global/about_ubs/corporate_responsibility/UBS-ESR-framework.pdf</ref>
The [[World Bank]] has analysed the value of the Protocol for use by their clients, concluding that it is a useful tool for guiding the development of sustainable hydropower in developing countries.<ref>{{Cite web|title = The Protocol for World Bank clients|url = http://documents.worldbank.org/curated/en/2014/06/20106007/hydropower-sustainability-assessment-protocol-use-world-bank-clients-lessons-learned-recommendations|website = documents.worldbank.org|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref>
The [[International Institute for Environment and Development]] has reviewed social and environmental safeguards for large dam projects, concluding that the Protocol currently offers the best available ‘measuring stick’ for the [[World Commission on Dams]] provisions.<ref>{{Cite web|title = A review of social and environmental safeguards for large dam projects|url = http://pubs.iied.org/17517IIED.html|website = pubs.iied.org|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref>
=== Process ===
A Protocol assessment takes place over a one-week period at the project site and provides a rapid sustainability check.
A Protocol assessment does not replace an [[Environmental impact assessment|environmental and social impact assessment]] (ESIA), which takes place over a much longer period of time as a mandatory regulatory requirement. A Protocol assessment will, amongst other things, check the scope and quality of the ESIA which has been done.
To ensure high quality, all commercial use of the Protocol is carried out by accredited assessors. These assessors have significant experience of the hydropower sector or relevant sustainability issues, and have passed a rigorous accreditation course.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hydropower Sustainability - Accredited Assessors|url = http://www.hydrosustainability.org/Protocol/Accredited-Assessors.aspx|website = www.hydrosustainability.org|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref>
== Scope ==
=== Tools === The Protocol can be used at any stage of hydropower development, from the early planning stages through to operation. Each project stage is assessed using a different tool: * The early stage tool, a screening tool for potential hydropower projects * The preparation tool, which covers planning and design, management plans and commitments. * The implementation tool, used through the construction phase. * The operation tool, used on working projects.
=== Topics === The Protocol covers a range of topics that need to be understood to assess the overall sustainability of a hydropower project.
The name and range of topics changes slightly at different project stages.
==== Social aspects ====
*Communications and consultation *Project benefits *Project affected communities and livelihoods *Resettlement *[[Indigenous peoples]] *Labour and working conditions *Public health *Cultural heritage
==== Environmental aspects ====
*Environmental and social assessment and management *[[Biodiversity]] and invasive species *[[Erosion]] and [[sedimentation]] *Water quality *Waste, noise and air quality *[[Reservoir]] planning / preparation and filling / management *Downstream flow regimes
==== Business aspects ====
*[[Governance]] *[[Procurement]] *Integrated project management *Financial viability *Economic viability
==== Technical aspects ====
*Demonstrated need and strategic fit *Siting and design *Hydrological resource *Asset reliability and efficiency *Infrastructure safety
The Protocol also includes ‘cross-cutting issues’ such as [[climate change]], [[gender]], and [[human rights]], which feature in multiple topics.
=== Criteria === For each sustainability topic, performance is assessed against a range of criteria at two levels: basic good practice and proven best practice.
==== Table 2: Criteria requirement at different levels. ==== {| class="wikitable" ! '''Criteria'''
! '''Basic Good Practice'''
! '''Proven Best Practice'''
|- | '''Assessment'''
| Adequate and effective assessment of the issues
| The assessment takes a broad view of the issues.
No significant opportunities for improvement.
|- | '''Management'''
| Adequate and effective management plans and processes
| Plans can anticipate and respond to new issues and opportunities.
No significant opportunities for improvement.
|- | '''Stakeholder Engagement'''
| Adequate and effective stakeholder engagement
| Project is inclusive and participatory. Feedback is provided. Stakeholders involved in decision-making.
No significant opportunities for improvement.
|- | '''Stakeholder Support'''
| General support amongst directly affected stakeholder groups
| Support of nearly all directly affected stakeholder groups.
In cases, formal agreements with consent of directly affected stakeholder groups.
|- | '''Conformance and Compliance'''
| No significant non-compliances and non-conformances
| No non-compliances and non-conformances.
|- | '''Outcomes'''
| Impacts are avoided, minimised, and mitigated, with no significant gaps
| Impacts are also compensated, and the project enhances pre-project conditions.
|}
== History == A multi-stakeholder forum developed the Protocol between 2008 and 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hydropower Sustainability - History|url = http://www.hydrosustainability.org/Protocol/Protocol-development.aspx|website = www.hydrosustainability.org|accessdate = 2015-10-01}}</ref>
The following key group were represented: social and environmental NGOs, governments of developed and developing countries, financial institutions, development banks, and the hydropower industry.
The forum jointly reviewed, enhanced and built consensus on what a sustainable hydropower project should look like.
Policies taken into account included the [[World Commission on Dams]]’ Criteria and Guidelines, World Bank Safeguard Policies, IFC Performance Standards, and the [[Equator Principles]].
A draft of the Protocol was released in 2009, which was trialled in 16 countries across six continents and subjected to further consultation involving 1,933 individual stakeholders from 28 countries.
The final version was produced in 2010.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Hydropower Sustainability - Download Protocol Document|url = http://www.hydrosustainability.org/Protocol/The-Protocol-Documents.aspx|website = www.hydrosustainability.org|accessdate = 2015-09-30}}</ref>
The diversity of the forum was important to ensure that the Protocol became globally applicable and universally accepted. Diversity also ensured that the multiple perspectives and stakeholder interests surrounding a hydropower project were incorporated into the document.
== Governance == The Protocol is governed by a multi-stakeholder body, the Hydropower Sustainability Assessment Council (HSA Council).<ref>http://www.hydrosustainability.org/Governance.aspx</ref>
The mission of the Council is to ensure multi-stakeholder input and confidence in the Protocol's content and application.
All individuals and organisations engaged in hydropower are welcome and encouraged to join the Council. This approach to governance ensures that all stakeholder voices are heard in the shaping of the use of the Protocol and its future development.
The Council consists of a series of Chambers, each representing a different segment of hydropower stakeholders. Each chamber elects a chair and alternate chair for a two-year term. The chamber chairs come together regularly to form the decision-making Protocol Governance Committee. The current Governance Committee (elected May 2015) is shown in the table below.
== References == {{Reflist}}

{{main|ISO 3166-2}}
'''ISO 3166-2:CM''' is the entry for [[Cameroon]] in [[ISO 3166-2]], part of the [[ISO 3166]] [[standardization|standard]] published by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which defines [[code]]s for the names of the principal [[country subdivision|subdivision]]s (e.g., [[province]]s or [[state (administrative division)|state]]s) of all [[country|countries]] coded in [[ISO 3166-1]].
Currently for Cameroon, ISO 3166-2 codes are defined for [[regions of Cameroon|10 regions]].
Each code consists of two parts, separated by a hyphen. The first part is {{mono|CM}}, the [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] code of Cameroon. The second part is two letters.
==Current codes== Subdivision names are listed as in the ISO 3166-2 standard published by the ISO 3166 Maintenance Agency (ISO 3166/MA).
[[ISO 639-1]] codes are used to represent subdivision names in the following [[official language|administrative language]]s: * (en): [[English language|English]] * (fr): [[French language|French]]
''Click on the button in the header to sort each column.''
{| class="wikitable sortable" ! Code ! Subdivision name ([[English language|en]]) ! Subdivision name ([[French language|fr]]) |- | {{mono|CM-AD}} | [[Adamaoua Region|Adamaoua]] | Adamaoua |- | {{mono|CM-CE}} | [[Centre Region (Cameroon)|Centre]] | Centre |- | {{mono|CM-ES}} | [[East Region (Cameroon)|East]] | Est |- | {{mono|CM-EN}} | [[Far North Region (Cameroon)|Far North]] | Extrême-Nord |- | {{mono|CM-LT}} | [[Littoral Region (Cameroon)|Littoral]] | Littoral |- | {{mono|CM-NO}} | [[North Region (Cameroon)|North]] | Nord |- | {{mono|CM-NW}} | [[North-West Region (Cameroon)|North-West]] | Nord-Ouest |- | {{mono|CM-SU}} | [[South Region (Cameroon)|South]] | Sud |- | {{mono|CM-SW}} | [[South-West Region (Cameroon)|South-West]] | Sud-Ouest |- | {{mono|CM-OU}} | [[West Region (Cameroon)|West]] | Ouest |}
==See also== * [[Subdivisions of Cameroon]] * [[List of FIPS region codes (A-C)#CM: Cameroon|FIPS region codes of Cameroon]]
==External links== * [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:CM ISO Online Browsing Platform: CM] * [http://www.statoids.com/ucm.html Regions of Cameroon], Statoids.com
{{ISO 3166}}

{{main|ISO 3166-2}} '''ISO 3166-2:DM''' is the entry for [[Dominica]] in [[ISO 3166-2]], part of the [[ISO 3166]] [[standardization|standard]] published by the [[International Organization for Standardization]] (ISO), which defines [[code]]s for the names of the principal [[country subdivision|subdivision]]s (e.g., [[province]]s or [[state (administrative division)|state]]s) of all [[country|countries]] coded in [[ISO 3166-1]]. Currently for Dominica, ISO 3166-2 codes are defined for [[parishes of Dominica|10 parishes]]. Each code consists of two parts, separated by a hyphen. The first part is {{mono|DM}}, the [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] code of Dominica. The second part is two digits (02–11). ==Current codes== Subdivision names are listed as in the ISO 3166-2 standard published by the ISO 3166 Maintenance Agency (ISO 3166/MA). ''Click on the button in the header to sort each column.'' {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Code ! Subdivision name ([[English language|en]]) |- | {{mono|DM-02}} | [[Saint Andrew Parish (Dominica)|Saint Andrew]] |- | {{mono|DM-03}} | [[Saint David Parish (Dominica)|Saint David]] |- | {{mono|DM-04}} | [[Saint George Parish (Dominica)|Saint George]] |- | {{mono|DM-05}} | [[Saint John Parish (Dominica)|Saint John]] |- | {{mono|DM-06}} | [[Saint Joseph Parish (Dominica)|Saint Joseph]] |- | {{mono|DM-07}} | [[Saint Luke Parish|Saint Luke]] |- | {{mono|DM-08}} | [[Saint Mark Parish (Dominica)|Saint Mark]] |- | {{mono|DM-09}} | [[Saint Patrick Parish (Dominica)|Saint Patrick]] |- | {{mono|DM-10}} | [[Saint Paul Parish (Dominica)|Saint Paul]] |- | {{mono|DM-11}} | [[Saint Peter Parish (Dominica)|Saint Peter]] |} ==Changes== The following changes to the entry have been announced in newsletters by the ISO 3166/MA since the first publication of ISO 3166-2 in 1998: {| class="wikitable" |- ! Newsletter ! Date issued ! Description of change in newsletter ! Code/Subdivision change |- | id="I-8" | [http://www.iso.org/iso/iso_3166-2_newsletter_i-8_en.pdf {{nowrap|Newsletter I-8}}] | {{nowrap|2007-04-17}} | Addition of the administrative subdivisions and of their code elements | style=white-space:nowrap | '''Subdivisions added:'''
10 parishes |} ==See also== * [[Subdivisions of Dominica]] * [[List of FIPS region codes (D-F)#DO: Dominica|FIPS region codes of Dominica]] ==External links== * [https://www.iso.org/obp/ui/#iso:code:3166:DM ISO Online Browsing Platform: DM] * [http://www.statoids.com/udm.html Parishes of Dominica], Statoids.com {{ISO 3166}} [[Category:ISO 3166|2:DM]] [[Category:Parishes of Dominica|*ISO 3166-2]] [[Category:Dominica-related lists]]

revision.text:
{{distinguish|text=the IOS statistical designation [[United States Minor Outlying Islands]]}} [[File:US insular areas-B.png|thumb|600px|Locations of the insular areas of the United States]]
An '''insular area''' of the [[United States]] is a [[Territories of the United States|U.S. territory]] that is neither a part of one of the 50 [[U.S. state|states]] nor of a [[Federal district]]. [[Article Four of the United States Constitution#Clause 2: Property Clause|Article IV, Section 3, Clause 2]] of the [[United States Constitution]] grants to [[United States Congress]] the responsibility of overseeing these territories,{{efn|Although an [[archaism]], some older federal statutes and regulations still in force refer to insular areas as ''possessions''.}} of which there are currently 14—three in the [[Caribbean Sea]] and 11 in the [[Pacific Ocean]].<ref name=USDoI>{{cite web| url=https://www.doi.gov/oia/islands/politicatypes| title=Definitions of Insular Area Political Organizations| publisher=U.S. Department of the Interior| location=Washington, D.C.| accessdate=March 3, 2018}}</ref> These territories are classified by whether they are incorporated (by Congress extending the full body of the Constitution to the territory as it applies to the several states), and whether they have an organized territorial government established by the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]] through an [[Organic Act]].<ref name=DotI>{{cite web| url=https://www.doi.gov/oia/islands/politicatypes| title=Definitions of Insular Area Political Organizations| publisher=U.S. Department of the Interior| location=Washington, D.C.| accessdate=March 11, 2018}}</ref> All territories but one are [[Unincorporated territories of the United States|unincorporated]], and all but four are considered to be [[Unorganized territory|unorganized]]. Five U.S. territories have a permanent, nonmilitary population. Each of them has a civilian government, a constitution, and enjoys some degree of local political [[autonomy]].
Congress has extended citizenship rights by birth to all inhabited territories except [[American Samoa]], and these citizens may vote and run for office in any U.S. jurisdiction in which they are residents. The people of [[American Samoa]] are [[United States nationality law#Nationals|U.S. nationals]] by place of birth, or they are U.S. citizens by parentage, or naturalization after residing in a State for three months.<ref>PBS Newshour, [https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/american-samoans-dont-right-u-s-citizenship-court-rules/ "American Samoans don't have right to U.S. citizenship"], Associated Press, June 5, 2015, viewed August 13, 2015.</ref> Nationals are free to move around and seek employment within the United States without immigration restrictions but cannot vote or hold office outside American Samoa.<ref>US Department of Interior. [http://www.doi.gov/oia/islands/american-samoa.cfm "Insular Area Summary for American Samoa"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150820064225/http://www.doi.gov/oia/islands/american-samoa.cfm |date=2015-08-20 }}. viewed August 13, 2015.</ref>
==Taxation== Residents of the five major populated insular areas do not pay U.S. federal [[income tax]]es but are required to pay other U.S. federal taxes such as import/export taxes,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://stanford.wellsphere.com/healthcare-industry-policy-article/puerto-rico/267827 |title=Puerto Ricans pay import/export taxes |publisher=Stanford.wellsphere.com |accessdate=August 14, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100401034052/http://stanford.wellsphere.com/healthcare-industry-policy-article/puerto-rico/267827 |archivedate=April 1, 2010 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| url=https://history.state.gov/historicaldocuments/frus1952-54v03/d903| title=Foreign Relations of the United States | author=U.S. State Dept.| quote=The people of Puerto Rico will continue to be exempt from Federal income taxes on the income they derive from sources within Puerto Rico, and into their treasury, for appropriation and expenditure as their legislature may decide, will be deposited the proceeds of United States internal revenue taxes collected on articles produced in Puerto Rico and the proceeds of United States tariffs and customs collected on foreign merchandise entering Puerto Rico.| accessdate=May 18, 2016}}</ref> federal commodity taxes,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://stanford.wellsphere.com/healthcare-industry-policy-article/puerto-rico/267827 |title=Puerto Ricans pay federal commodity taxes |publisher=Stanford.wellsphere.com |date= |accessdate=2011-10-30 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100401034052/http://stanford.wellsphere.com/healthcare-industry-policy-article/puerto-rico/267827 |archivedate=2010-04-01 |df= }}</ref> social security taxes, etc. Individuals working for the federal government pay [[Income tax in the United States|federal income tax]]es while all residents are required to pay federal [[payroll tax]]es ([[Social Security (United States)|Social Security]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.irs.gov/taxtopics/tc903.html |title=Internal Revenue Service. ', Topic 903 – Federal Employment Tax in Puerto Rico', |publisher=Irs.gov |date=December 18, 2009 |accessdate=August 14, 2010}}</ref> and [[Medicare (United States)|Medicare]]). According to [[U.S. Internal Revenue Service|IRS]] Publication 570, income from other U.S. [[Pacific Ocean]] insular areas ([[Howland Island|Howland]], [[Baker Island|Baker]], [[Jarvis Island|Jarvis]], [[Johnston Island|Johnston]], [[Midway Islands|Midway]], [[Palmyra Atoll|Palmyra]], and [[Wake Island|Wake]] Islands, and [[Kingman Reef]]) is fully taxable as income of United States residents.<ref>{{cite book |title=Publication 570 |publisher=U.S. Internal Revenue Service |year=2017 |place=Washington, D.C.|url=https://www.irs.gov/pub/irs-pdf/p570.pdf |accessdate=April 12, 2018}}</ref>
==Associated States==
The [[United States Department of State|U.S. State Department]] uses the term insular area to refer not only to territories under the [[sovereignty]] of the United States, but also those independent nations that have signed a [[Compact of Free Association]] with the United States. While these nations participate in many otherwise domestic programs, and full responsibility for their military defense rests with the United States, they are legally distinct from the United States and their inhabitants are not United States citizens or nationals.<ref name=USDoI/>
==List and status of insular areas==
The following islands, or island groups, are considered insular areas of the United States:
===Organized incorporated territories=== ''None''
===Unorganized incorporated territories=== One (uninhabited) * {{flag|Palmyra Atoll}} The U.S. Territory of Palmyra Island (Mostly owned by the federal government and the [[Nature Conservancy]]; administered by the [[U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service]])
===Organized unincorporated territories=== Four (all inhabited) * {{flag|Guam}} (organized under the [[Guam Organic Act of 1950]]) * {{flag|Northern Mariana Islands}} ([[Commonwealth (U.S. insular area)|Commonwealth]], organized under 1975 covenant) * {{flag|Puerto Rico}} (Commonwealth, organized under the [[Puerto Rico Federal Relations Act of 1950]]) * {{flag|United States Virgin Islands}} (organized under the 1954 [[Revised Organic Act of the Virgin Islands]])
===Unorganized unincorporated territories=== Eleven (one inhabited, ten uninhabited) * {{flag|American Samoa}} (Self-governing, even though officially unorganized; officially under authority of the [[United States Department of the Interior|U.S. Department of the Interior]]) * [[Bajo Nuevo Bank]] ''(disputed with Colombia, Honduras and Jamaica)'' * {{flag|Baker Island}} * {{flag|Howland Island}} * {{flag|Jarvis Island}} * {{flag|Johnston Atoll}} * {{flag|Kingman Reef}} * {{flag|Midway Atoll}} (administered as a [[National Wildlife Refuge]]) * {{flag|Navassa Island}} ''(disputed with Haiti)'' * [[Serranilla Bank]] ''(disputed with Colombia, Jamaica and Nicaragua)'' * {{flag|Wake Island}} ''(disputed with Marshall Islands)''
===Freely associated states=== From July 18, 1947 until October 1, 1994, the U.S. administered the [[Trust Territory of the Pacific Islands]], a [[United Nations Trust Territory]]. Later the U.S. entered into new political relationships with each of the four political units. One is the Northern Mariana Islands listed above. The others being the three [[associated state|freely associated states]] below. The freely associated states are the three sovereign states with a [[Compact of Free Association]] with the United States where the U.S. provides national defense, funding, and access to social services. * {{flag|Federated States of Micronesia}} * {{flag|Marshall Islands}} * {{flag|Palau}}
===Former territories=== * {{flag|Panama Canal Zone}}{{snd}}acquired through the 1903 [[Hay–Bunau-Varilla Treaty]]; abolished October 1, 1979, as a term of the 1977 [[Torrijos–Carter Treaties]].{{efn|The [[Panama Canal]] itself was under joint U.S.–[[Panama]]nian control from 1979 until it was fully turned over to Panama on December 31, 1999.}} * {{flag|Philippines}}{{snd}}acquired through the 1898 [[Treaty of Paris (1898)|Treaty of Paris]]; U.S. sovereignty relinquished and the independence of the [[Republic of the Philippines]] recognized July 4, 1946, through the [[Treaty of Manila (1946)|Treaty of Manila]].
== See also == * [[Dependent territory]] * [[Guano Islands Act]] * [[Guantanamo Bay Naval Base|Guantanamo Bay]] * [[Insular Cases]] * [[Political divisions of the United States]] * [[Territorial acquisitions of the United States]] * [[Territories of the United States on stamps]]
== Notes == {{notelist}}
== References == {{reflist}}
== External links == {{Commons category|Insular areas of the United States}}
* [https://web.archive.org/web/20070617145659/http://www.doi.gov/oia/Firstpginfo/islandfactsheet.htm Office of Insular Affairs] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110721034923/http://www.doi.gov/oia/Islandpages/political_types.htm Department of the Interior Definitions of Insular Area Political Types] * [https://www.theatlantic.com/issues/2001/02/rubin.htm Rubin, Richard, "The Lost Islands"], ''[[The Atlantic Monthly]]'', February 2001 * [https://web.archive.org/web/20131014000647/http://www.census.gov/geo/www/GARM/Ch7GARM.pdf Chapter 7: Puerto Rico and the Outlying Areas], U.S. Census Bureau, Geographic Areas Reference Manual
{{United States political divisions|state=expanded}} {{United States topics}} {{Terms for types of country subdivisions}}

revision.text:
{{Politics of the Philippines}} The '''Legislative Districts of Manila''' are the representations of the [[Cities of the Philippines|city]] of [[Manila]] in the [[Template:Philippine legislative periods|various national legislatures]] of the [[Philippines]]. The city is currently represented in the [[Philippine House of Representatives|lower house]] of the [[Congress of the Philippines]] through its [[#1st District|first]], [[#2nd District|second]], [[#3rd District|third]], [[#4th District|fourth]], [[#5th District|fifth]], and [[#6th District|sixth]] districts. {| class="wikitable" !District !Barangays !Area !Population (2015) |- |1 |1 - 146 |4.57 km2 |415,906 |- |2 |147 - 267 |4.08 km2 |215,457 |- |3 |268 - 394 |6.24 km2 |221,780 |- |4 |395 - 586 |5.14 km2 |265,046 |- |5 |649 - 828 |11.56 km² |366,714 |- |6 |587–648 829–905 |7.79 km² |295,245 |} ==History== Manila was originally divided into two [[House of Representatives of the Philippines#District representation|representative districts]] from 1907 to 1949. When seats for the [[Senate of the Philippines|upper house]] of the [[Philippine Legislature]] were elected from territory-based districts between 1916 and 1935, the city formed part of the [[Senatorial districts of the Philippines#Fourth District|fourth senatorial district]] which elected two out of the 24-member senate. In the disruption caused by the [[Second World War]], Manila was incorporated into the City of Greater Manila on January 1, 1942 through [[Manuel Quezon]]'s Executive Order No. 400 as a wartime emergency measure. Greater Manila was represented by [[#1943–1944|two delegates]] in the [[National Assembly of the Second Philippine Republic|National Assembly]] of the Japanese-sponsored [[Second Philippine Republic]]: one was the city mayor (an [[ex officio member|''ex officio'' member]]), while the other was elected through a citywide assembly of [[KALIBAPI]] members during the [[Japanese occupation of the Philippines]]. Upon the restoration of the [[Philippine Commonwealth]] in 1945, Manila's pre-war two-district representation was retained; this remained so until 1949. By virtue of the ''Revised Charter of the City of Manila'',{{cite web |title=Republic Act No. 409 |author=Congress of the Philippines |date=June 18, 1949 |accessdate=June 13, 2016 |url=http://www.chanrobles.com/republicacts/republicactno409.html}} enacted on June 18, 1949, the city was divided into four congressional districts. The city elected four representatives from the [[Second Congress of the Philippines|2nd Congress]] up to the [[Seventh Congress of the Philippines|7th Congress]]. The city was represented in the [[Interim Batasang Pambansa]] as part of [[Interim Batasang Pambansa#Regional Representatives|Region IV]] from 1978 to 1984, and elected [[#1984–1986|six representatives]], at large, to the [[Regular Batasang Pambansa]] in [[Philippine parliamentary election, 1984|1984]]. Manila was reapportioned into six [[House of Representatives of the Philippines#District representation|congressional districts]] under the new Constitution{{cite web |title=1987 Constitution of the Philippines - Apportionment Ordinance |url=http://www.gov.ph/constitutions/the-1987-constitution-of-the-republic-of-the-philippines/the-1987-constitution-of-the-republic-of-the-philippines-ordinance/ |accessdate=June 13, 2016}} which was proclaimed on February 11, 1987. It elected members to the restored House of Representatives starting [[Philippine legislative election, 1987|that same year]]. ==1st District== [[Image:Ph fil congress manila 1d.png|thumb|right|Manila's current first district highlighted.]] *'''[[Manila#City|District]]''': [[Tondo, Manila|Tondo]] (western area) *'''[[Barangay]]s''': 1–146 *'''Area''': 4.57 km² *'''Population (2015)''': 415,906 {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center; width:40%;" |- !width=40%|Period !Representative |- |[[8th Congress of the Philippines|8th Congress]]
